Coral bleaching rates vary at different times because it depends where the coral reefs live at.
Every few years winds are altered.
This causes the trade winds to weaken or completely change direction.
Also, because in order for corals to live they must be in a water temperatures between 70-85F.
However, when surface water shifts eastward, ocean waters temperature can increase by 3-5F and in some places the water temperature can increase over 10F above the customary range.
This is not healthy because if the water temperature increases too much, the corals might be in danger.
Another reason why coral bleaching rates vary at different times is because the process of photosynthesis is sensitive to changes in water temperature.
If the water temperature increases, the solubility of carbon dioxide in water decreases.
The decrease in carbon dioxide disrupts the process of photosynthesis and this will not keep the corals healthy.
Finally, coral bleaching rates can happen at different times depending on the zooxanthellae.
The zooxanthellae has a symbiotic relationship with the corals so they both benefit from eachother.
If the zooxanthallae dies, the corals will bleach and turn white.

Increased stress on the corals from the environment like blast fishing, tourists who drop anchors can cause the coral to eject the zooxanthallae and then the corals will bleach and make the corals diseased.
If the coral goes for too long without zooxanthallae, bleaching can result in death.

There are many events that can lead to coral bleaching.
One of them, which is possibly the greatest factor, is the temperature of the water.
Water temperature in Pacific Ocean, where the worst case of coral bleaching ocurred, can change drastically.
The change in water temperature is known as upwelling.
Upwelling is when the wind drags warm surface water westward, and the cooler water in the eastern Pacific else to the surface.
However, the winds that drag the water are often altered, making them weaker  or reverse direction completely to blow from west to east.
This causes the central and eastern Pacific regions to warm.

According to the article ?Trade Winds and Coral Bleaching,? in 1998, the tradewinds in the Pacific became weaker by nearly 10 meters per second, causing the temperature of the water to rise about 3 degrees faranheit.
In that same year, over 70 countries reported coral bleaching around the Pacific Ocean.
However, water temperature does not cause coral bleaching directly. Zooxanthallae, or algae, are contributors to a coral?s color.
Algea live in the coral tissues and need light for photosynthesis.
This process provides the coral with carbon in the farm of glycerol or glucose.
These chemicals provide corals with the energy they need to survive.
When the water temperature rises, algae stops providing corals with glucose.
Therefore, the coral can?t support a lot of algae, so its forced to expell  algae.
This causes a coral to become weak and unhealthy, and is also loses it?s color.
This makes corals vulnerable to disease and starvation.
If it goes for too long without algae, bleaching can result in the death of the coral.
